0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Dibotermin alfa has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Degenerative disease of the central nervous system, Autogenous bone graft substitute in single-level lumbar interbody spine fusion: Typical dose: 4 mg (2.7 cm(3), one-third of matrix) IMPLANTED with lumbar interbody fusion device or into the anterior portion of the intervertebral disc space; determine required volume by size, shape, and internal volume of the lumbar interbody fusion device and the intervertebral disc space; MAX: 8 mg (5.3 cm(3), two-thirds of matrix) in intervertebral disc space (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Tibia fracture, Acute, using open fracture reduction and intramedullary unreamed nail fixation; Adjunct: Typical dose: 1 pack (12 mg dibotermin alfa) IMPLANTED per fracture site; determine volume of matrix to use by the fracture anatomy and ability to close wound without overly packing or compressing product; MAX 2 full matrices (24 mg dibotermin alfa) (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Safety and efficacy in pediatric patients younger than 18 years not established

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Degenerative disease of the central nervous system, Autogenous bone graft substitute in single-level lumbar interbody spine fusion
  • Tibia fracture, Acute, using open fracture reduction and intramedullary unreamed nail fixation; Adjunct

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Active infection at the operative site
  • Active malignancy or undergoing treatment for malignancy
  • Hypersensitivity to dibotermin alfa or any component of the product
  • Pathological fractures, including Paget disease or in metastatic bone
  • Persistent compartment syndrome or neurovascular residua of compartment syndrome
  • Skeletal immaturity

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Immunologic:
  • -- Antibody formation has been reported
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- Heterotopic ossification of implantation site or surrounding tissue has been reported
  • -- Posterior bone formation, sometimes leading to nerve compression requiring surgery, has been reported with degenerative disk disease treated by posterior lumbar interbody fusion
  • -- Trabecular bone resorption has been reported; direct application to trabecular bone not recommended when bone resorption may increase risk of bone fragility
  • -- Does not provide mechanical stability
  • Other:
  • -- Severe localized edema (sometimes leading to airway compromise) has been reported in patients undergoing cervical spine surgery; use not recommended
  • -- Fluid collection formation, which may be encapsulated and sometimes leading to nerve compression, has been reported; clinical intervention may be necessary
  • -- Patients with history or clinical suspicion of application site malignancy; use not recommended
  • -- Device migration, sometimes requiring surgery, has been reported
  • -- Patients with reamed nails in open tibial fracture; use not recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Other:Localized infection (19% to 21%)
Serious
  • Musculoskeletal:Heterotopic ossification (1% to less than 10%), Increased bone formation, Localized edema (1% to less than 10%)
  • Neurologic:Radiculopathy (1% to less than 10%)
  • Other:Abscess (1% to less than 10%), Migration of implant or internal device (1% to less than 10%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Implantation
  • Handle product with forceps.
  • Minimize fluid loss and do not squeeze.
  • Prepare immediately prior to use.
  • Place 1 syringe, 1 needle, and matrix inner package in sterile field; use the second syringe to inject 8.4 mL of solvent into the dibotermin alfa vial, and then discard second syringe; swirl gently; do not shake.
  • Peel open matrix inner package (leave in tray) and use the syringe placed in sterile field to withdraw 8 mL of reconstituted dibotermin alfa solution; distribute uniformly on the matrix.
  • Final dibotermin alfa concentration is 1.5 mg/mL (12 mg per vial); do not exceed this concentration.
  • Wait 15 minutes before using the prepared dibotermin alfa product; use within 2 hours.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Use with approved (CE-marked) lumbar interbody fusion device; product is compatible with titanium, polyetheretherketone (PEEK), and allograft bone.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Do not overfill fusion device or anterior portion of intervertebral disc space.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Cut wetted matrix into 6 equal pieces of approximately 2.5 cm x 5 cm; additional cuts may be made as required.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Loosely fill hollow geometry of fusion device carefully and corresponding to the internal volume of the device.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Do not implant matrix posterior to fusion device where access to spinal canal or nerve root may be possible; a physical barrier between matrix and neurological tissue is required if leakage into spinal canal or nerve root is possible.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Do not irrigate inside of intervertebral disc space once matrix and fusion device are implanted; however, any fluid loss from wetted matrix outside of the intervertebral disc space should be rinsed away.
  • Lumbar interbody fusion surgery: Preferred placement of any required surgical drain is 1 layer superficial to implantation site; drain must be placed remotely from implantation site.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Achieve definitive fracture reduction, fixation, and hemostasis prior to use of matrix.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Fold or cut matrix as needed prior to implantation.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Implant following completion of standard fracture and wound management (ie, at the time of soft tissue closure).
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Cover accessible surface area of fracture (ie, lines and defects) to the extent possible, placing the matrix to bridge the fracture region while making good contact with the major proximal and distal fragments.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Matrix may be placed loosely packed (folded, rolled, or wrapped) into a void, as required by the geometry of the fracture, but do not use to fill void in presence of compressive forces as matrix does not provide mechanical stability.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Do not irrigate wound after matrix is placed.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: Preferred placement of any required surgical drain is 1 layer superficial to implantation site; drain must be placed remotely from implantation site.
  • Acute tibia fracture surgery: For maximum efficacy, completely cover matrix with soft tissue following implantation.
